questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is the earliest sign in Crohn's disease?
questions.explanation:
Aphthous ulcers, surrounded by a rim of erythematous mucosa, are the earliest lesions seen in a 
patient with Crohn's disease during endoscopy. Crohn's colitis usually spares the rectum and is most severe in the ileocaecal region. • In early Crohn's disease, small, punched-out aphthous ulcers are often seen (the result of 
submucosal lymphoid follicle expansion). • In moderate disease, the aphthous ulcers coalesce into larger ulcers, which may take on the 
appearance of a star (stellate ulcers). • As disease severity increases, submucosal edema and injury can result in cobblestoning of the 
mucosa (option A) and eventually the formation of serpiginous ulcers, which are typical findings 
in Crohn's disease. Thorn-like extraluminal projections in barium studies are known as rose-thorn appearance, and 
are a typical sign of Crohn's disease. They represent deep penetrating linear ulcers or fissurings 
typically seen within stenosed terminal ileum with a thickened wall. (Options C and D)

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is true about Crohn's disease?

options.a: For effective treatment of a Crohn's mass, only antibiotics are prescribed.
options.b: Symptomatic relapse after surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection.
options.c: The proximal ileum is most commonly involved in Crohn's disease.
options.d: On endoscopic examination, continuous lesions are visualised, which are diagnostic of Crohn's

questions.explanation:
Symptomatic relapse of Crohn's disease after surgery is not related to the presence of the disease 
during resection. The course of the disease after surgery is unpredictable since surgery does not cure Crohn's 
disease. Instead, the probability of relapse increases with the time since resection. Other options: Option A: Antibiotics alone cannot treat a Crohn's mass effectively. Abscesses can be treated with 
metronidazole and ciprofloxacin and should also undergo drainage (and resection if needed). Option C: The terminal ileum is most commonly involved in Crohn's disease. Option D: On endoscopic examination, discontinuous "skip" lesions are visualized. These are 
irregular areas of inflamed mucosa that are ulcerated with mucopurulent exudate separated by 
intervening, normal-appearing intestinal mucosa.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 40-year-old female patient presents with a 9-month history of weight loss, abdominal 
cramps, and intermittent diarrhea. On examination, a palpable mass in the right lower 
quadrant of the abdomen is found. Stool cultures are normal. Colonoscopy shows the 
presence of skip lesions. Biopsy showed the presence of non-caseating granulomas. What is 
the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
520 
Sold by @itachibot The clinical scenario and the biopsy showing the presence of non-caseating granulomas are 
diagnostic of Crohn's disease.

questions.question:
Question 4: 508 
Sold by @itachibot A 28-year-old patient was brought to the casualty ward with high fever and pain abdomen. He 
had a history of bloody diarrhea for several months. His past history was negative for 
long-term medications and previous surgeries. The abdominal X-ray image obtained is shown 
below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario and the radiograph are suggestive of toxic megacolon. Toxic megacolon may present with fever, abdominal pain, and abdominal distension. Abdominal 
radiography shows transverse or right colonic dilation of >6 cm and loss of haustrations. It is 
usually associated with ulcerative colitis as indicated by history of chronic bloody diarrhoea. It can be triggered by electrolyte imbalance and narcotics which interfere with gut motility. 
Features of secondary bacterial infecton and sepsis may be present. It can be complicated by 
intestinal perforation. It usually resolves with supportive treatment (correcting electrolyte imbalance, fluids, and bowel 
rest) and medical therapy which includes glucocorticoids, anti-inflammatory drugs, and 
antibiotics. However, an urgent colectomy is indicated in patients who do not show signs of 
improvement. Indications for urgent surgery include: • Frank intraperitoneal peritonitis, secondary to perforation • Life-threatening hemorrhage or increasing transfusion requirements • Worsening systemic toxicity • Worsening colonic dilatation Other options: Option B: Volvulus occurs when the air-filled segment of the colon twists around the mesentery. 
The sigmoid colon is the most commonly involved part of the large intestine (90%). The patient 
can present with abdominal distension, nausea and vomiting. X-ray abdomen shows a bent inner 
tube or coffee bean appearance. 521 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Ogilvie syndrome, also known as colonic pseudo-obstruction is a functional disorder 
with colonic dilatation without mechanical obstruction. It occurs commonly in hospitalized 
patients and is associated with narcotics, bed rest and comorbid disease. X-ray shows dilatation of 
the colon (predominantly transverse colon) with absent mechanical obstruction. Option D: Pneumatosis intestinalis is the presence of gas within the bowel wall seen in any part of 
the GI tract but most commonly in the jejunum. It is a pathognomic feature of necrotizing 
enterocolitis. X-ray of the abdomen will show intramural gas in the bowel.

questions.question:
Question 5: You are doing an emergency laparotomy for a case of intestinal obstruction. Which organ will 
you first visualize to know if this is a case of small bowel or large bowel obstruction?
questions.explanation:
The cecum is the first organ to be visualized to differentiate between the small and large bowel in 
cases of intestinal obstruction. 522 
Sold by @itachibot Distension of the cecum will confirm large bowel involvement. The identification of a collapsed 
distal segment of the large bowel and its sequential proximal assessment will lead to the 
identification of the cause.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 55-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of intermittent constipation and a 
sense of heaviness in his lower abdomen. His barium enema film is given below. Which of the 
following statements is false about the pathology responsible for his condition? 509 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Commonly occurs along the mesenteric side of the colon
options.b: Sigmoid colon is the most common site
options.c: It is characterized by true diverticula

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray film showing saw-toothed appearance of the colon are 
suggestive of colonic diverticulosis. They are false diverticula. Diverticulosis refers to the herniation of the mucosa and muscularis mucosa through the colonic 
wall, usually at the point where the nutrient artery enters the colon (mesenteric side). The 
condition is usually asymptomatic until complications arise. They may be detected incidentally. 
On a barium X-ray, the colon with diverticular disease will have a saw-toothed appearance. Colonic diverticula are more often acquired than congenital. They are common in developed 
countries that have a low fiber diet. A low fiber diet results in low stool volume. As the colon 
generates higher intraluminal pressure to propel smaller volumes of stools, low stool volumes 
cause an increase in colonic wall tension and segmentation of the colon. Prolonged colonic contractions and high pressures (directed radially along the colonic wall) 
results in the formation of pulsion diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common site. Note: True diverticulum involves the herniation of all the layers of the intestine whereas false 
diverticulum involves the herniation of only the mucosa and submucosa.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is true regarding left-sided diverticulitis?

options.a: It is often an incidental finding during surgery
options.b: Appendicitis is an important differential diagnosis
options.c: Left sided diverticulitis is more common than right
options.d: The anatomical location is given by the Hinchey classification

questions.explanation:
In the general population, left-sided diverticulitis is more common. The sigmoid colon (left colon) 
involvement is more common than the right colon involvement. 523 
Sold by @itachibot Diverticulitis is the inflammation and infection of the diverticulum. It most commonly presents 
with • left lower abdominal pain (often termed as left-sided appendicitis) • fever • a change in bowel habits • anorexia, nausea • urinary urgency if there is an associated inflammation of the bladder etc. Right-sided diverticulitis occurs more often in younger patients of Asian descent than in other 
populations and presents with pain in the right lower quadrant. Patients presenting with these 
symptoms are often thought to have acute appendicitis, and often the diagnosis of right-sided 
diverticulitis is subsequently made in the operating room. The Hinchey classification is used to describe the severity of the diverticular disease, complicated 
by perforation. Hinchey classification: Stage 1 
Mesenteric or pericolic absce 
ss Stage 2 
Pelvic abscess Stage 3 
Purulent peritonitis Stage 4 
Fecal peritonitis

questions.question:
Question 8: A 38-year-old man is brought to the casualty with severe right lower quadrant abdominal 
pain for the last two days. You suspect right-sided diverticulitis due to the relatively long 
history and lack of migration of pain. However, your co-resident is convinced it is 
appendicitis. Which is the best investigation to rule in your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis is now considered by most to be the 
standard modality for the evaluation of acute diverticulitis. Contrast enema studies are the most accurate way to find out the colonic diverticula. However, 
because of the risks of extravasation of barium from the perforation and aggravation of 
inflammation, it is avoided. In contrast to barium enema, a CT scan demonstrates both the intraluminal and extracolonic 
manifestations of acute right-sided diverticulitis. CT findings include pericolic soft tissue stranding, colonic wall thickening and pericolic fat 
infiltration (streaky fat). 524 
Sold by @itachibot Barium enema in diverticulosis shows a saw-tooth appearance.

questions.question:
Question 9: While performing surgery on a patient who presented with clinical features suggestive of 
peritonitis, a diverticular perforation is seen along with fecal peritonitis. What is the 
Hinchey's stage?
questions.explanation:
Fecal peritonitis belongs to grade 4 in the Hinchey classification. Diverticulitis refers to the inflammation and infection associated with the diverticula. Hinchey 
classification is the most commonly used classification for the severity and complication of acute 
diverticulitis. It is used additionally to guide the overall management of acute diverticulitis. Hinchey classification: Stage 1 
Mesenteric or pericolic absce 
ss 525 
Sold by @itachibot Hinchey classification: Stage 2 
Pelvic abscess Stage 3 
Purulent peritonitis Stage 4 
Fecal peritonitis

questions.question:
Question 10: A 70-year-old man with past history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and chronic 
constipation presented with right lower abdominal pain associated with fever. CT abdomen 
findings are suggestive of acute diverticulitis with 6 cm fluid accumulation in the paracolic 
region. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.a: Oral antibiotics, bowel rest and continued monitoring
options.b: iv antibiotics, bowel rest, and continued monitoring
options.c: Laparotomy for abscess drainage and surgical resection
options.d: CT guided percutaneous drainage with iv antibiotics

questions.explanation:
The elderly patient with multiple comorbidities and complicated acute diverticulitis (fluid 
collection >5 cm) should ideally be managed with CT-guided percutaneous drainage with iv 
antibiotics. Acute diverticulitis management: Outpatient care • Initiated for young patients with no comorbidities • It includes: • Liquid diet • Analgesia • Regular follow-up Inpatient care • Should be initiated if CT shows complicated diverticulitis characterized by: • Perforation • Abscess formation • Obstruction or • Fistulization. • Can also be initiated if CT shows uncomplicated diverticulitis but the patient is of high risk such 
as • Sepsis at presentation • Elderly patient • Immunosuppression • Presence of comorbidities • Failure of outpatient care • Inpatient care includes the following: • Bowel rest • IV fluids • Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics 526 
Sold by @itachibot • Antibiotic therapy can be continued with careful monitoring if fluid collection is <5 cm • CT guided percutaneous drainage if antibiotic therapy fails or fluid collection is > 5 cm • Surgical exploration and resection if there is perforation, obstruction, or fistulization • Regular follow-up with imaging Note: Oral antibiotics have no proven benefit in the outpatient management of acute 
uncomplicated diverticulitis.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 55-year-old man is brought to the casualty with a history of fever and abdominal pain. The 
pain was initially in the left lower quadrant for 2 days but is diffuse and severe for the past 4 
hours. The erect X-ray of the chest showed the presence of pneumoperitoneum. Emergency 
laparotomy was performed. It showed the presence of perforated left-sided diverticulitis with 
fecal peritonitis. How will you manage the patient?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of fecal peritonitis due to perforation of left-sided diverticulitis. 
This is managed by Hartmann's procedure. It involves segmental resection, a proximal-end 
colostomy, and closure of the rectal stump. If the perforation of the diverticulitis leads to a localized pericolic abscess formation, then it is 
treated with antibiotics alone or along with percutaneous drainage.

questions.question:
Question 12: An elderly male patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain, increased 
frequency of micturition, and passing of air bubbles in urine. He was diagnosed with 
diverticulitis 2 years before and was treated with antibiotics. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The history of diverticulitis and pneumaturia point towards a diagnosis of colovesical fistula. The 
patients present with the symptoms of urinary tract infection caused by colonic flora, 
pneumaturia (air bubbles in urine), and fecaluria (foul-smelling and brownish material in the 
urine). Complications of diverticular disease: • Bleeding • Perforation leading to a pericolic abscess or generalized peritonitis 527 
Sold by @itachibot • Intestinal obstruction due to fibrosis • Fistula formation (colovesical, coloenteric, colovaginal) Emphysematous cystitis can also present with pneumaturia. It is caused by urinary tract infection 
(UTI) with a gas-forming organism, especially in people with diabetes or patients with urinary 
tract outflow obstruction.

questions.question:
Question 13: A CECT confirmed severe acute diverticulitis in a 34-year-old brought to the emergency with 
lower abdominal pain. A Foley's catheter was promptly placed to prevent a certain 
complication. Which of the following statements is false regarding the complication?

options.b: Contrast enema is used to identify the course the pathology
options.c: Previous hysterectomy may increase the risk
options.d: It more commonly occurs in females

questions.explanation:
The colovesical fistula is more common in men than in women because the uterus prevents the 
sigmoid from adhering to the bladder. Hence, females who have undergone hysterectomy are at increased risk. Clinical features of a colovesical fistula are: • Pneumaturia (flatus in urine) • Fecaluria (feces in urine) • Suprapubic pain • Dysuria • Urgency • Frequency • Gross hematuria (rare) Pneumaturia is usually appreciated toward the end of urination because the collection of gas 
usually sits at the top of the bladder. The finding pneumaturia or fecaluria is virtually 
pathognomonic for urinary tract fistulas, and patients presenting with this condition should be 
presumed to have a colovesical fistula and investigated accordingly. Over time, cystitis associated with a colovesical fistula may evolve to pyelonephritis. An abdominopelvic CT with oral or rectal contrast is the investigation of choice. A contrast enema 
may be used to identify the course of the fistula.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient presented with fever, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. She has a history of recent 
intensive care unit admission for sepsis which required prolonged antibiotic therapy. 
Sigmoidoscopy findings are given below. Choose the false statement regarding the given 
condition. 512 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy is done in fulminant disease
options.b: IV vancomycin is used for treatment of recurrent disease
options.c: Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is an emerging treatment option
options.d: Stool sample is used for PCR detection of toxins

questions.explanation:
A history of diarrhea associated with prolonged antibiotic treatment and characteristic adherent 
pseudomembranes in the colon is highly suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis. Oral 
Fidaxomicin is commonly used in recurrent pseudomembranous colitis. The causative antibiotic agent must be discontinued and infection control measures must be taken 
for all patients. • Initial episode - non severe: WBC 15,000/mm3, Creatinine < 1.5 mg/dL • Oral Fidaxomicin(drug of choice) or Vancomycin • Oral Metronidazole can be given if Vancomycin/Fidaxomycin is not available 528 
Sold by @itachibot • Initial episode - severe: >15,000/mm3, Creatinine >1.5 mg/dL • Oral Fidaxomicin or Vancomycin • Consider fecal microbiota transplantation • Initial episode - fulminant • Hypotension, ileus or megacolon • Oral vancomycin and IV metronidazole • Rectal Vancomycin can be used if ileus present • Overwhelming sepsis, colonic perforation, or peritonitis • Subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy • First recurrence • Repeat course of antibiotics for another 10-20 days • Oral Fidaxomicin(drug of choice) or Vancomycin can be used. • Repeated recurrence • Consider fecal microbiota transplantation Option A: Subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy is the procedure of choice for patients requiring 
surgery for severe colitis or toxic megacolon. It allows for disease control, stabilization, and 
preservation of reconstruction options for the future. Segmental colectomy, ileostomy, or 
colostomy alone does not address the pancolonic nature of the disease. Option C: Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is emerging as a promising treatment option for 
recurrent and recalcitrant C. difficile infection. Using FMT, donor stool is administered to the 
patient through one of a variety of described routes (nasogastric tube, colonoscopic lavage, or 
upper endoscopy) to restore colonic flora. Option D: Pseudomembranous colitis is caused by Clostridium difficile which is a gram-positive, 
spore-forming anaerobic microorganism. The pathogenesis is mediated by the enterotoxins - toxin 
A and toxin B. They can be detected in the stool using PCR

questions.question:
Question 15: An elderly male patient is brought to the casualty with complaints of vomiting and severe 
abdominal pain. The abdomen appears grossly distended, is tender to touch, and percussion 
reveals hyper-resonance. His X-ray abdomen is shown in the image below. What is the next 
best step in the management of this patient? 513 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Laparotomy followed by sigmoid resection alone
options.d: Insertion of a rectal tube through a flexible sigmoidoscope

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray radiograph showing characteristic coffee bean 
appearance are highly suggestive of sigmoid volvulus. Non-operative decompression followed by 
insertion of a rectal tube through a rigid proctoscope or a flexible sigmoidoscope is the next best 
step in the management of this patient. Sigmoid volvulus is a cause of large bowel obstruction and occurs when the sigmoid colon twists 
on the sigmoid mesocolon. Symptoms include constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea, and/or 
vomiting. Onset may be acute or chronic. It occurs more commonly in patients with a history of 
mental illness and chronic constipation. X- ray abdomen shows a large, dilated loop of the colon, often with a few air-fluid levels. Specific 
signs include the coffee bean sign and the absence of rectal gas. CT may reveal large gas-filled 
loop without haustral markings, forming a closed-loop obstruction. 529 
Sold by @itachibot Non-operative decompression is successful in treating 90% of the patients. The rectal tube should 
be left in place for 1-2 days to allow complete decompression and to prevent immediate recurrence 
of the volvulus. This should be followed by bowel cleansing with cathartics and a complete 
colonoscopic examination. In patients with signs of colonic necrosis or in whom endoscopic 
detorsion has failed, sigmoid colectomy with the closure of the rectum and end colostomy 
(Hartmann procedure) maybe required. Even if detorsion of the sigmoid is successful, elective 
sigmoid resection is indicated to prevent recurrence.

questions.question:
Question 16: A lady is brought to the casualty department with a 2-day history of diffuse abdominal pain. 
She has had several episodes of bloody diarrhea for the past 8 hours and appears dehydrated. 
On examination, her pulse is feeble and BP is 80/55 mmHg. An abdominal x-ray shows the 
"thumbprinting sign.” What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The thumbprinting sign is seen in both ischemic colitis and pseudomembranous colitis. Bowel wall "thumbprinting" (the appearance of thumbprint-shaped projections) is a radiological 
sign of submucosal thickening of the colonic wall. It can result from any process that leads to 
edema of the bowel wall, including pseudomembranous colitis, ischemic colitis, non-infective 
inflammatory bowel disease, other infective bowel diseases, as well as submucosal/intramural 
hemorrhage. The plain abdomen x-ray given below shows submucosal thickening with crescentic margins of the 
colon described as "thumbprinting" sign.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 44-year-old female patient presents to the casualty with complaints of sudden onset of pain 
in the abdomen. On examination, there is a palpable tympanic swelling in the left side of the 
abdomen. X-ray abdomen of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most 
likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette and the X-ray findings are suggestive of caecal volvulus. It is 
differentiated from sigmoid volvulus as there is only a single air-fluid level and the apex of the 
volvulus pointing towards the left upper quadrant. It is commonly seen in females in the 4th and 5th decade who can present with partial or 
complete intestinal obstruction. The clinical features include: • Marked abdominal distention 530 
Sold by @itachibot • Abdominal pain • Obstipation • Nausea and vomiting etc. On examination, a palpable tympanic swelling in the midline or the left side may be seen. If there 
is strangulation or perforation of the obstructed bowel segment, peritoneal signs (rigidity, 
rebound tenderness etc.) can be present. Radiological findings include caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level, and absence of gas in the 
distal colon. On X-ray abdomen, the apex of the cecal volvulus points towards the left upper 
quadrant ( vs apex pointing towards the right upper quadrant in sigmoid volvulus) CECT abdomen is the investigation of choice that shows a whirl sign (also seen in the midgut 
volvulus). Management of cecal volvulus includes supportive therapy with nasogastric tube, iv fluids, 
antibiotics etc. and early surgical intervention. • Perforated or strangulated cecal volvulus should be treated with right hemicolectomy • If there is no sign of perforation or strangulation, either cecopexy or right hemicolectomy can be 
performed. Option B: Sigmoid volvulus (image shown below) is a cause of large bowel obstruction and occurs 
when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon. X-ray abdomen shows a large, dilated 
loop of the colon, often with a few air-fluid levels. Specific signs include the coffee bean sign 
and the absence of rectal gas. On X-ray abdomen, the apex of the sigmoid volvulus points towards 
the right upper quadrant. Option C: Toxic megacolon (image shown below) is defined as the dilatation of the transverse 
colon to a diameter of more than 6 cm. It is usually associated with severe ulcerative colitis. It can 
be triggered by electrolyte imbalance and narcotics as they interfere with gut motility. 531 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Fecal retention is an accumulation of a large amount of stool within any bowel segment, 
most commonly within the colon usually due to chronic constipation. A colonic distention with 
fecal material is often called fecal loading on the radiograph. It can be complicated by fecal 
impaction and subsequent bowel obstruction.

questions.question:
Question 18: A middle-aged woman underwent an open repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The 
procedure was uneventful. However, on the 2nd postoperative day, the patient developed 
symptoms of acute abdomen and bloody diarrhea with significant guarding. The patient was 
taken up for an exploratory laparotomy. Which of the following areas is most likely to be 
involved?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of ischemic colitis and it occurs most commonly at the splenic 
flexure. Ischemic colitis occurs due to interruption or decrease in colonic blood flow. It may occur with 
many different conditions, including embolism from cardiac disease, low-flow states such as 
congestive heart failure, sepsis, and vasopressor use. Major vascular surgery (both open and 
endovascular repair), especially involving the abdominal aorta, is a well-known risk factor for 
developing ischemic colitis. Although any area of the colon may be affected, the watershed areas of the splenic flexure 
(Griffith’s point) and the rectosigmoid (Sudeck’s point) are the most prone to ischemia because of 
the often incomplete anastomoses of the marginal artery in these locations. The next most 
common area afflicted is the cecum, secondary to low blood flow in the terminal branches of the 
ileocolic artery. Splenic flexure (also known as Griffith's point) is a watershed area between the superior and 
inferior mesenteric arteries. Sudeck point is a watershed area between the sigmoid arterial branch from the inferior mesenteric 
artery and the superior rectal artery (branch of Inferior mesentric artery). 532 
Sold by @itachibot The marginal artery of Drummond runs parallel to the colon, connecting the SMA and IMA 
circulation - the majority of blood flow to the left and sigmoid colon in case of occlusion of the 
IMA. Arc of Riolan is a variable collateral vessel that connects the SMA (middle colic vessel) to the IMA 
(left colic).

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient had a painless episode of profuse per rectal bleeding. After initial stabilization, a 
colonoscopy was performed. The findings are given below. What is the most common site of 
this condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario and colonoscopy findings are suggestive of angiodysplasia. The cecum is the 
most common site of angiodysplasia followed by the colon. In the colon the angiodysplasia can occur anywhere, however it is commonly found in the right 
colon than the transverse and the left colon. 533 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: A patient being evaluated for recurrent lower GI bleeding secondary to colonic angiodysplasia 
is suspected to have Heyde syndrome. What are the other common features associated with 
the condition?

options.c: Aortic stenosis and von Willebrand disease

questions.explanation:
Heyde’s syndrome is a multisystem disorder characterized by the clinical triad of: • Aortic stenosis • Gastrointestinal bleeding from angiodysplasia • Acquired type 2 vWD (secondary to valvular stenosis, returns to normal once the valve is 
replaced) Dilated mucosal and submucosal veins are usually seen on colonoscopy.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 4-month-old infant presented with constipation since birth. On a per rectal exam, a sudden 
release of feces was seen. A contrast enema showed a dilated descending colon leading to a 
constricted segment. Which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of the disease?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario, with a positive blast sign (sudden release of feces on PR examination) 
and characteristic barium enema findings, are suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. Patients with 
Hirschsprung’s disease have an increased frequency of mutations in certain genes such as glial cell 
line-derived neurotrophic factor (GCDNF). GDNF promotes the survival, proliferation, and migration of neural crest cells in culture. GDNF is 
expressed in the gut in advance of migrating neural crest cells and is chemoattractive for neural 
crest cells in culture. Mutations are also seen its receptor Rearranged during Transfection 
(RET), or its coreceptor Gfra-1 (GDNF family receptor alpha-1). Gene mutations in chromosomes 10 and 13, family history, and Down’s syndrome are also factors 
associated with Hirschsprung’s disease.

questions.question:
Question 22: A neonate was brought to the pediatrician on day 5 of life with bilious vomiting and failure to 
pass meconium. On examination, the abdomen was distended. and X-Ray showed distended 
bowel loops. Due to suggestive family history, the resident suspected Hirschsprung's disease. 
What is the gold standard investigation for this condition?
questions.explanation:
A rectal biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease. It shows the following: • Absent ganglia • Hypertrophied nerve trunks • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase • Calretinin immunostaining (superior to acetylcholinesterase staining) Anorectal manometry is an important screening tool. It shows the absence of rectoanal inhibitory 
reflex.

questions.question:
Question 23: From which of the following sites should a rectal biopsy be taken in order to confirm the 
diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease?
questions.explanation:
534 
Sold by @itachibot The ideal site to obtain a rectal biopsy in a patient with Hirschsprung's disease is from a point that 
is at least 2 cm above the dentate line. The internal sphincter extends up to 2 cm above the 
dentate line. This region is normally devoid of ganglionic cells. Hence, biopsy in this region may 
lead to errors in the results. Rectal biopsy is the gold standard investigation in patients with Hirschsprung's disease. It shows 
the presence of hypertrophied nerve trunks and the absence of ganglion cells.

questions.question: Question 24: All of the following are surgeries you may plan in a child with aganglionic megacolon, except?
questions.explanation:
Heineke-Mikulicz's operation is a type of pyloroplasty and is not done for aganglionic megacolon 
(Hirschsprung disease). Surgery is the treatment of choice for Hirschsprung disease. A multi-stage approach may be 
adopted. A colostomy is done in the newborn period, followed by a definitive pull-through 
operation after the child is over 10 kgs. Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows: • Swenson • Duhamel • Soave

questions.question:
Question 25: What is the most common problem that arises postoperatively following surgery for 
Hirschsprung's disease?
questions.explanation: Constipation is the most common postoperative problem after surgery for Hirschsprung disease. Other problems are soiling, incontinence, and postoperative enterocolitis.

questions.question:
Question 26: Up to what length from the anal verge will you be able to visualize through a flexible 
sigmoidoscope?
questions.explanation:
Flexible sigmoidoscope is 60 cm in length and can be used to visualize the rectum and sigmoid 
colon. Flexible sigmoidoscopy is a procedure involving the following steps: A sigmoidoscope is inserted through the anus and the distal colonic mucosa (up to 60 cm from the 
anal verge) is visualized. Diagnostic or therapeutic maneuvers are performed, as needed. 535 
Sold by @itachibot Scope 
Length Anoscope 
8 cm Proctoscope 
15 cm Rectoscope 
25 cm 60 cm Flexible sigmoidosco

questions.question: Question 27: Which structure would you trace to identify enlarged paracolic lymph nodes?

options.c: Main branches of the superior mesenteric artery
options.d: Named branches of inferior mesenteric artery

questions.explanation:
Paracolic lymph nodes are located along the marginal artery. 536 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 28: A 50-year-old man presents with 2 episodes of bleeding per rectum over the past 2 hours. His 
vitals are stable. Per rectal examination was normal except for trace evidence of fresh blood. 
Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention for this patient?
questions.explanation:
In case of suspected lower GI bleeding or hematochezia, if the hemodynamic status of the patient 
is stable, colonoscopy with appropriate bowel preparation should be done at the earliest. A patient 
with hematochezia or fresh blood per rectum should be managed in the following way: Hemodynamically unstable on initial assessment (or suspected massive UGI bleed): • At first, resuscitation with iv fluids, blood transfusion, and volume replacement • Perform EGD (Esophagogastroduodenoscopy) • Consider getting gastro surgery/interventional radiology consult • If a source is not found on EGD, • Perform angiography ± embolization if still hemodynamically unstable • Perform colonoscopy if the patient is hemodynamically stable or, if a source was not identified 
on initial angiography • If colonoscopy did not identify a bleeding source, consider further evaluation with • Capsule endoscopy • Tagged red blood cell scan • Repeat EGD, etc. Hemodynamically stable on initial assessment: • Bowel preparation and perform colonoscopy • If a source was not found on colonoscopy, EGD should be performed • If a source was not found even on EGD, consider further evaluation with • Capsule endoscopy 537

questions.question:
Question 29: A 56-year-old man with weight loss and pallor comes to the physician. A CBC and Fe studies 
indicate iron deficiency anemia. The patient denies any history of bleeding disorders or 
changes in diet. A guaiac test is advised. What parameter does it test?
questions.explanation:
Guaiac test is used for testing occult blood in the stool. New-onset iron deficiency anemia in 
middle-aged men should be thoroughly evaluated for colorectal carcinoma, even in the absence of 
other symptoms. Principle: Guaiac is a colorless organic compound that turns blue upon oxidation by oxidants, 
peroxidases, or pseudoperoxidase of hemoglobin. The test is more sensitive for lower GI bleed. Fecal hemoglobin must exceed 10 mg/g of stool (blood loss of 10 ml daily), for the test to be 
positive in 50% of the cases, although the test can be positive in some cases even if hemoglobin is 
<1mg/g of stool.
